Author: lifthrasiir
Content: I think neither ISO 2022 nor UTF-16/32 have never seen use in filesystem, exactly for this reason. Author: tikhonj
Content:
Haskell is fundamentally different from Ruby et al. It has plenty of features for achieving the same goals--say modularity--but there is no 1:1 mapping between those features and Ruby features. Or any OOP features at all.

Basically, you can do the same things but not necessarily in the same ways. For example, Haskell does not have any inheritance the way OO languages do, so that simply doesn&

Author: theblackswan
Content:
I will partly agree as sometime the problem is due to flash as for scrubbing it must pass on the time and accept the nearest Key frame. But most of the time it is related to netwrok, bandwidth and server packet dispatches.

While seeking a new timeline the network and the backend server has to be very receptive. For very popular videos only key frames positions can be cached to enhance experience. \nWe at our video website have made a genuine attempt to optimize these issues. http://bquobe.com/\nlet me know your feedback on our buffering and seeking.

Author: maxst
Content:
> Lossy and transparent? Out of luck.

Well, you could lossy-optimize PNGs if you really want to. Take Google front page logo, for example: not a lot of colors to justify using 32 bpp PNG. Just sacrifice some alpha bits, and you can switch to 256-color indexed PNG. I bet nobody would notice the difference, and the result would be a lot smaller.

Author: theblackswan
Content:
Youtube is using adaptive bitrates which keeps checking the connection and push the quality 480,720p etc, but the process is error prone and do too much of polling thus killing user experience. We at our video website: http://bquobe.com/ have tried to overcome these problems by just generating network token once and streaming accordingly. We have also optimized buffer and random timeline seeking. Currently, the bug for video starting from 0.00s when quality is toggled exists. We would be fixing it soon.

There wont be much of a difference with native h264 support just probably limited and related to html5 applications.

Again, this parsing is trivial if you use parser combinators of (almost) any kind.
